bug.short_desc: Performance: Look for ways to lazily initialize palette

long_desc.thetext:
From what I understand, the GEF palette requires the entire palette definition to be passed to it upon initialization. For large products that have hundreds of palette items, it can take substantial amounts of time to create this palette definition. (Especially if the palette definition is built from parsing extension points).
I would like this bug to serve as a placeholder for investigating ways that GEF could lazily initialize the palette, instead of requiring the entire definition be passed to it on creation.

I thought the purpose of extension points is that they are fast, since they avoid plugin activation. Isn't the workbench's New Wizard Dialog populated using extension points? It is also a tree structure that probably contains hundreds of items. Is the tree lazily populated?
You can share your palette root across all instances of the same editor type.

bug.short_desc: palette view should update if page in MultiPageEditorPart changes

long_desc.thetext:
We have a MultiPageEditorPart extension with quite a few pages, two of which use a palette (GraphicalEditorWithFlyoutPalette). The two pages that use the palette can be different palettes.
This is no problem when the "Palette View" is not open, as each palette is maintained by the page. The issue is that the palette view seems to only be loaded once per editor - ie: the MultiPageEditorPart. If the current inner editor has a palette when the palette view is loaded, then the palette view will consist of that particular palette, even if the page (inside the MPE) is changed to a page that doesn't support a palette, or a page with a different palette.
What should happen is that if the active editor inside the MultiPageEditorPart changes, the palette view should also update to reflect the current editor's palette, if any.
Is this any different than the Outline View and Properties View? See bug 46207.

It's hard for me to tell exactly what's going on in 46207; I assume by pointing me towards there, you're saying similar problems exist for the outline and properties views?
(I'm not experiencing issues with those views, though it may be because we've put some hacks around them...)

bug.short_desc: org.eclipse.jdt.apt.tests.annotations.mirrortest.MirrorTestAnnotationProcessor.testPackagegImpl fails assertion test on IBM Java2 5.0

long_desc.thetext:
The following line in the testPackageImpl fails the assertion because it finds 80 classes within java.util rather than 79.
ProcessorTestStatus.assertEquals("Number of classes in java.util", 79, classes.size());
I'm running these tests on a PowerPC platform and don't have access to a Sun JRE so I don't know why there apparently is a difference of one class in java.util.
Assuming that the IBM Java2 java.util package is ok, and contains the correct classes, this test should be changed to tolerate the result from the IBM JRE.
Similar to the problem we have with 1.6. We need to move away from a dependency on anything in rt.jar.
The related bug (for Java 1.6) is bug 152534.
Test rewritten so that it looks for specific types rather than just counting the size of the returned collection.
*** Bug 188935 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: Software Updates - Specify update sites all at once

long_desc.thetext: When trying to update Eclipse, it is very fragmented by having to choose update sites throughout the process. It would be nice to specify the sites first and then get all the updates at once so the update can go through unattended. And better yet, allow user to save choices for sites and only prompt if the user's choice is not available. This would also probably require a preference page to allow the user to change their choices.

bug.short_desc: ECF tests are disorganized

long_desc.thetext:
The ECF test plug-ins are pretty messy at the moment.
Observations: -license headers missing Pick any file from org.eclipse.ecf.test, pretty sure others suffers the same problem. -unnecessary dependencies in MANIFEST.MF org..eclipse.jdt.junit, what's that all about? Seems like it's just printing messages (see below). "Hard" or "soft" dependencies that ends up pointing to org.eclipse.ui is causing a _new Eclipse instance_ to boot when running the tests, see org.eclipse.ecf.test, org.eclipse.ecf.test.remoteservice, possibly others, this makes tests take a while to load :( -class placement and names Why does org.eclipse.ecf.test depend and test on things declared in org.eclipse.ecf.test.provider? Not sure about the convention about this, but I think test implementations should go in a *.internal.* folder whereas tests (classes that extends TestSuite or TestCase) should go in a *.tests.* folder to clearly distinguish the two, not sure what's the verdict on abstract classes though (see org.eclipse.ecf.test.IDTestCase). Packages with tests are *.tests.* and not *.test.* per Eclipse naming conventions.
Things that may not matter: -tests do not test against API From what I skimmed, I noticed that the org.eclipse.ecf.test.provider tests are all running against stuff implemented within the plug-in itself instead of real (public API) implementations, what purpose does this serve? -print statements are meaningless Unit tests are (generally) meant to be automated. It's unlikely that anyone's going to read that output unless the tests fail, which, if the user knows what they are doing, they could just add their own print statements, or if the user is new to ECF and just running tests, he or she wouldn't know what it means anyway. Perhaps we could make do with the "Sleeping for ..." messages since it indicates that the test isn't just 'hung', but all those event print messages seems kind of useless to me.

Created an attachment (id=52286) Patch to remove unnecessary dependencies and reorganize org.eclipse.ecf.test.
This patch allows org.eclipse.ecf.test to run stand-alone from other test plug-ins. It adds org.eclipse.ecf.test.provider.generic.CreateSharedObjectTest to AllTests, but from a diff, I notice it seems to differ little from org.eclipse.ecf.test.CreateSharedObjecTest, so one of the two should probably just be deleted.
DataSharingServiceTest runs all green on my machine, so I removed the main(String[] method).
TestContainerTest is testing stuff in org.eclipse.ecf.test.provider, so that needs to move over there. JUnitTestRunListener looked utterly useless, so I killed that too.

The TestContainerTest class from org.eclipse.ecf.test should be added to org.eclipse.ecf.test.provider. That package actually has no classes extending TestCase but instead uses a rather crude method of having a main(String[]) method in TestContainer itself. The tests needs to be extracted from TestContainer or just removed if TestContainerTest covers it anyway.
Peter, added you to CC, can you comment on this?

I also noticed that tests generally don't have a declared dependency on a provider even though you need to. If you try to run it you can't get the IContainer because the provider implementation of the IContainer isn't hooked onto the ContainerFactory class.
(In reply to comment #2) > Peter, added you to CC, can you comment on this?
Meant to say, I added you to CC since you seem to be the author of those files according to the class level javadocs.

org.eclipse.ecf.test.provider plugin should probably just go away? Peter?
(In reply to comment #3) > I also noticed that tests generally don't have a declared dependency on a > provider even though you need to. If you try to run it you can't get the > IContainer because the provider implementation of the IContainer isn't hooked > onto the ContainerFactory class. > > (In reply to comment #2) > > Peter, added you to CC, can you comment on this? > > Meant to say, I added you to CC since you seem to be the author of those files > according to the class level javadocs. >
Scott, I think you're right -- this plugin was an early attempt of mine to put together a minimal container suitable for unit testing. It never quite materialized and can be safely removed.
(From update of attachment 52286) Recent refactoring efforts seems to have borked things up a bit, I'll try to run a diff later and produce a workable patch for HEAD later.

Remy,
I think we should just delete this plugin 'org.eclipse.ecf.test.provider'.
RE: tests changes...yes need to reorganize/refactor/break down tests into smaller units. I've got other stuff first for a week or so.
If you or others are able to help create new tests/refactor existing tests it would be most welcome.
RE: jdt.junit dependencies...don't know
(In reply to comment #6) > (From update of attachment 52286 [edit]) > Recent refactoring efforts seems to have borked things up a bit, I'll try to > run a diff later and produce a workable patch for HEAD later. >

(In reply to comment #7) > I think we should just delete this plugin 'org.eclipse.ecf.test.provider'.
You don't mean that literally, do you? The "real" refactoring work at the moment is just affecting org.eclipse.ecf, so org.eclipse.ecf.provider isn't going to do any splitting, right? Any newly created tests may need to go in org.eclipse.ecf.test.provider, so you are keeping the folder but just removing the "fake" tests for the moment, right?

(In reply to comment #8) > (In reply to comment #7) > > I think we should just delete this plugin 'org.eclipse.ecf.test.provider'. > > You don't mean that literally, do you? The "real" refactoring work at the > moment is just affecting org.eclipse.ecf, so org.eclipse.ecf.provider isn't > going to do any splitting, right? Any newly created tests may need to go in > org.eclipse.ecf.test.provider, so you are keeping the folder but just removing > the "fake" tests for the moment, right?
Yes. Let's the existing classes and putting in new test cases but keeping the plugin around.
>

Created an attachment (id=52658) Project-level refactoring patch for org.eclipse.ecf.test.remoteservices to reorganize code/dependencies.
This patch performs the following...
.classpath: Sets the JRE container to J2SE-1.4.
MANIFEST.MF: Removes the dependency on org.eclipse.ui and the Activator code since this test does not require life cycle management. Adding org.eclipse.ecf.provider.remoteservices as the tests depends on that provider plug-in's implementation of the interfaces defined within org.eclipse.ecf.remoteservices.
org.eclipse.jdt.core.prefs: Sets the compiler to be compliance level at 1.4
Activator.java: Deleted per comment for MANIFEST.MF.
IConcatTest.java: Added the licensing header.
RemoteServiceTest.java: Added a license header and additional assertion checks for testCallRemoteServiceWithProxy(). Created a new testCallRemoteServiceAsynch() test method which checks for successes and failures (such as a method's name being incorrect, incorrect number of parameters, etc.).

I think one thing that may be worth considering is setting up a set of abstract TestCase subclasses.
These subclasses would reside in their own projects based on the API they're testing (such as org.eclipse.ecf.tests.datashare). Any datashare implementing container could extend them and implement the getID() and getArguments() methods for container instantiation in their own tests project (org.eclipse.ecf.tests.provider.datashare, the names are getting kind of long though, not sure if that's a problem).
This approach could help ensure that all providers are tested according to the same specifications (that being whatever's defined in the javadoc API of said interface).

I've started a brand new test plugin: org.eclipse.ecf.tests (note 's' :). I've gone about refactoring the tests and made some progress at it for the core and identity plugin classes (Namespace, IDFactory, StringID, ContainerFactory, etc. etc). More to do, but now much better organized...e.g. abstract super classes to make the test cases more compact.
Will be going about redoing other tests in this model, and moving new test cases into existing org.eclipse.ecf.tests plugin, or other new test plugins e.g. org.eclipse.ecf.tests.remoteservice, org.eclipse.ecf.tests.filetransfer, org.eclipse.ecf.tests.datashare (none of these created yet).
(In reply to comment #11) > I think one thing that may be worth considering is setting up a set of abstract > TestCase subclasses. > > These subclasses would reside in their own projects based on the API they're > testing (such as org.eclipse.ecf.tests.datashare). Any datashare implementing > container could extend them and implement the getID() and getArguments() > methods for container instantiation in their own tests project > (org.eclipse.ecf.tests.provider.datashare, the names are getting kind of long > though, not sure if that's a problem). > > This approach could help ensure that all providers are tested according to the > same specifications (that being whatever's defined in the javadoc API of said > interface). >

(In reply to comment #12) > I've started a brand new test plugin: org.eclipse.ecf.tests (note 's' :)
Just thought about this, but shouldn't this be in the 'tests' folder instead of the 'plugins' folder (in the eclipse.org CVS structure I mean).

(In reply to comment #13) > (In reply to comment #12) > > I've started a brand new test plugin: org.eclipse.ecf.tests (note 's' :) > > Just thought about this, but shouldn't this be in the 'tests' folder instead of > the 'plugins' folder (in the eclipse.org CVS structure I mean). >
True. I moved the org.eclipse.ecf.tests plugin over to the org.eclipse.ecf/tests module. Removed the copy in plugins directory.
Marking this bug as fixed and creating new (more specific) bug(s) for tests associated with various ECF extension APIs (presence, discovery, datashare)

Created new tests plugins (in tests module):
org.eclipse.ecf.tests.datashare org.eclipse.ecf.tests.presence org.eclipse.ecf.tests.sharedobject org.eclipse.ecf.tests.discovery org.eclipse.ecf.tests.filetransfer
Moved test cases out of org.eclipse.ecf.tests and into respective API test plugins as described above.
There is more test code to add for each of these APIs, but I'm marking this bug fixed and individual other bugs can be filed.

bug.short_desc: [DataBinding] doCreateBinding only works with old BindSpec

long_desc.thetext:
I found a problem on
"org.eclipse.jface.internal.databinding.provisional.DataBindingContext" class, method doCreateBinding. This method receives a "org.eclipse.jface.databinding.BindSpec", however the method body refers to "org.eclipse.jface.internal.databinding.provisional.BindSpec" deprected class so the following code never will create a binding if we pass a valid BindSpec instance (with custom converters and formatters), because an instance of "org.eclipse.jface.databinding.BindSpec" will never be an instance of "org.eclipse.jface.internal.databinding.provisional.BindSpec" so the following exception will be fired:
No binding found for target: org.eclipse.jface.internal.databinding.internal.swt.TextObservableValue, model: org.eclipse.jface.internal.databinding.internal.observable.NestedObservableValue
CODE IN doCreateBinding in DataBindingContext
if (bindSpec==null || bindSpec instanceof BindSpec) { binding = factory.createBinding (originatingContext, targetObservable, modelObservable, (BindSpec)bindSpec); } If we tried to use the not deprected DataBindingContext class we don't have functionality to deal with Master/Detail use case.
We think this is a refactoring problem.
Please, fix it.

The code is in a half refactored state as the provisional APIs are being moved to public APIs and there is also some cleanup going on. I'm not sure if it's worth the effort to fix this and other possible issues. I'll leave that up to Boris to make the call. But I believe that you can work around this in your own code. Instead of passing an instance of org.eclipse.jface.databinding.BindSpec you can pass an instance of org.eclipse.jface.internal.databinding.provisional.BindSpec since it extends from the refactored BindSpec. That should satisfy the public API and pass the instanceof checks.

Yes, this is an artifact of the ongoing refactoring. You can only use the "old" BindSpec with the "old" DataBindingContext, even though the method signatures use the "new" BindSpec. The reason for this is that the various setters on BindSpec return a "new" BindSpec, and making the signatures in the "old" DataBindingContext to only take "old" BindSpec objects, existing code would have compile errors.
I won't fix this (workaround is to only instantiate the "old" BindSpec when using the old DataBindingContext).
For master/detail with the new API, please have a look at the package org.eclipse.jface.databinding.observable.masterdetail. I'd be interested in feedback.

bug.short_desc: [DataBinding]

long_desc.thetext:
Hello
We created a custom control and we need to integrate it with DataBinding Functionality, however we don't see a clean mechanism to do it. We need an easy way to integrate custom controls with databindg functionallity.
Please, add this functionality to databinding. Currently our workaround is to bind the internal SWT control, however this is error phrone.

Can you please provide more information about what you're attempting to do? Data Binding provides interfaces and some default implementations for existing SWT widgets. If these implementations don't satisfy your use cases you can create your own, and for custom controls you might have to. But without a use it's hard to say what the issue is here.

bug.short_desc: [Regression]The color of the word in layout didn't change after changing its color in General tab(Only select color in the dropping list).

long_desc.thetext: Description: [Regression]The color of the word in layout didn't change after changing its color in General tab(Only select color in the dropping list). Steps to reproduce: 1, New a label in a new report. 2, Enter some words. 3, Select the label and set its color in General tab. 4, Only change the color from the dropping list. 5, Check the color in Layout, then preview it. Expected result: The word's color can change successfully both in layout and in preview. Actual result: There is no change in layout, but can be changed in preview. Error logs:no

It's model's bug. In bug 152951, Xuelan said that when using a color, GUI should call PropertyHandle.getIntValue() directly.
But I found that if DesignElementHandle.getProperty( StyleHandle.COLOR_PROP )== "blue" or other color strings, DesignElementHandle.getPropertyHandle( StyleHandle.COLOR_PROP ).getIntValue( ) are always == 0.
I think it's model's fault. Can model verify it, thanks.
Yes, it's model's bug. There's some problem in PropertyHandle.getIntValue(). We will check the codes in soon.
Fixed.
verified and closed
